children.name: sth that you cannot be certain about
uncertain
children.definition: /not certain  something that is uncertain, has not been definitely shown or decided:
examples: ▪ The cause of the accident is uncertain.
▪ Exactly how and when these plant species came to the Great Plains is not certain.

children.name: it is uncertain whether/if
examples: ▪ It is still uncertain whether the conference will actually take place.

children.name: it is uncertain how/why/when/that
examples: ▪ It’s uncertain when the trial will begin.
▪ It is not at all certain that Christopher Columbus was the first European to discover America.

children.name: unclear
children.definition: /not clear  a situation that is unclear, is one that people do not know enough or understand enough to be sure about it:
examples: ▪ The causes of the dispute are not entirely clear.
▪ At this hour, the fate of the passengers and crew is still unclear.
it is unclear how/why/whether etc
▪ It isn’t clear how the fire started.
▪ It’s not yet clear whether the disease is caused by a virus.
▪ It was unclear when the two sides would meet again to discuss the budget.
it is not clear that
▪ It’s not clear that the problems with the new computer system have been worked out.
unclearadjective không rõ ràng; không minh bạch; khó hiểu
If you are unclear about something, you are not certain about it
_I'm unclear about a couple of points in your proposal - could you go over them again?
_I'm unclear(as to) whether we're meant to stay here or not.

children.name: up in the air
children.definition: be   informal use this about something that is uncertain because a decision has not yet been made:
examples: ▪ I might be going on a training course next week, but it’s still up in the air.
▪ They still haven’t said if I’ve got the job -- it’s all up in the air at the moment.

children.name: there is uncertainty
children.definition: about/over something use this to say that people do not feel certain about what has happened or will happen, and are worried about it - used especially in newspapers and public speeches:
examples: ▪ The Principal said there was uncertainty about the candidate’s qualifications.
▪ There is some uncertainty over where the refugees are going to be housed.
uncertaintynoun[ C or U ]
when something is not known, or something that is not known or certain
_Nothing is ever decided, and all theuncertainty is very bad for staff morale.
_Life is full of uncertainties.

children.name: when there are several different opinions about sth
debatable
children.definition: it is debatable whether
examples: ▪ It is debatable whether these alternative medical treatments actually work.

children.name: a debatable point
examples: ▪ Whether or not the government was right to arrest the protesters is an extremely debatable point.

children.name: questionable c2
children.definition: questionable  something that is questionable seems doubtful and is likely to be wrong or untrue:
examples: ▪ The conclusions of the survey are questionable because the research was based on a very small sample of people.

children.name: it is questionable whether
examples: ▪ It is questionable whether the advertisements will increase sales.

children.name: open to question
children.definition: /debate  something that is open to question or open to debate seems doubtful and needs to be checked or discussed:
examples: ▪ Many people feel that the safety of the drug is now open to question.
▪ Just why the guerrillas decided to shoot down the unarmed plane remains open to debate.

children.name: it is open to question/debate whether
examples: ▪ It is open to debate whether the new government is any better than the old one.

children.name: moot point
children.definition: something that different people have different opinions about: điểm gây tranh cãi

children.name: ▪ I’m not sure that bringing in computers has made our job easier. It’s a moot point
examples: ▪ Whether or not increasing taxes will result in a fairer society remains a moot point.

children.name: when two different results are possible
go either way U
children.definition: sth could go either way informal if you say that something such as a game or a decision could go either way, you mean that either of two results is equally possible:
examples: Legal experts following the case believe the trial could go either way.
Spurs are a goal up but there are ten minutes to go and the match could still go either way.

children.name: borderline
children.definition: a borderline case is a situation in which the decision is not certain, for example about whether someone should pass an exam, get a job etc: ranh giới, giới tuyến

children.name: borderline case/decision etc
examples: In borderline cases we look at a student’s class work to decide the final exam result.
It was a borderline decision whether to send him to prison or not.

children.name: fifty-fifty chance
children.definition: there’s a  spoken informal if you say there is a fifty-fifty chance of sth happening, you mean there is an equal chance of it happening or not happening:
examples: ▪ The weather forecast said there was a fifty-fifty chance of rain.

children.name: be fifty-fiftythere is a fifty-fifty chance
examples: ▪ It’ll be a tough game -- I’d say our chances of winning are fifty-fifty.

children.name: toss-up
children.definition: it’s a  spoken say this when you do not know which of two possibilities someone will choose, and you think each is equally likely:
examples: ‘Have you decided where to go on holiday?’ ‘Well, it’ll be either Portugal or Turkey -- it’s a toss-up.’
it’s a toss-up between
I don’t know who’ll get the job. I guess it’s a toss-up between Carl and Steve.

children.name: when a situation is uncertain, and sth bad may happen
uncertain
examples: ▪ The situation on the island is still very uncertain and the army is on full alert.
▪ The long-term benefits of the treatment are extremely uncertain.
▪ The economic outlook is so uncertain that I would think carefully before investing any money.

children.name: highly uncertainvery uncertain
examples: ▪ The company faces a highly uncertain future.

children.name: doubtful
children.definition: be/look/remain etc   to be uncertain and likely to be bad:
examples: ▪ The result of the President’s re-election campaign remains doubtful.
▪ With more and more cuts in government spending, the program’s future now seems doubtful.

children.name: it is doubtful if/whether
examples: ▪ It is doubtful if she will survive the operation.
▪ It is extremely doubtful whether the aid is actually reaching the people who need it most.

children.name: it is doubtful that
examples: ▪ It is doubtful that the governor’s proposed tax increase will be popular with voters.

children.name: in doubt
children.definition: be   if someone or something’s future or success is in doubt, it seems very uncertain and they may not be able to continue or to succeed:
examples: ▪ After yet another injury, his football career is in doubt.
▪ The building’s future remained in doubt until the government agreed to restore it.

children.name: touch and go
children.definition: it’s  spoken you say it’s touch and go when a situation seems extremely uncertain and you are worried that something may not happen in the way you want:
examples: ▪ It was touch and go for a few hours, but we were able to get everything out of the basement before it flooded.
▪ An urgent operation was needed to save his life, and doctors said it was touch and go until the end of the procedure.

children.name: it’s touch and go whether
examples: ▪ Traffic was really heavy, and for a while it was touch and go whether they’d get to the wedding on time.

children.name: in the balance
children.definition: be/hang   if something is in the balance or hangs in the balance, there is a risk that something bad will happen so that it will not continue:
examples: ▪ The survival of the African elephant hangs in the balance.
▪ His career as a politician hung in the balance
.▪ I can’t say what the outcome of the talks will be -- they’re very much in the balance at the moment

children.name: iffy
children.definition: use this to describe a plan or situation that seems uncertain and may not succeed or happen as you want:

children.name: ▪ ‘What’s happening about your new job?’ ‘The whole thing’s rather iffy at the moment.’
examples: ▪ I was hoping to go to the beach today but it’s looking iffy because of the weather.

children.name: not sure if sth is true or if sth will happen
not certain
children.definition: not sure about something. Not certain is more formal than not sure: không chắc
examples: ▪ The man you’re looking for could be Keith, but I’m not certain.

children.name: not certain about: không chắc về điều gì
examples: ▪ I’m not certain about what time the buses come - I usually cycle.

children.name: not certain how/why/where etc: không chắc như thế nào/tại sao/ở đâu
examples: ▪ I’m really not certain how much fuel we’ve got left.

children.name: not know
children.definition: to not be at all sure if something is true or if something will happen: không biết/không chắc
examples: ▪ ‘How old is she?’ ‘Oh, I don’t know - fifty, fifty-five?’
not know if/whether/how etc: không chắc nếu/liệu/như thế nào
▪ I phoned her but I don’t know if she got my message.
▪ We do not know whether the lake is safe for swimming in.
not know for sureespeciallyspoken:không biết chắc
▪ It could be this week but it might be much later. We don’t know for sure.

children.name: unsure
children.definition: /uncertainB2  Unsure and uncertain are more formal than not sure and not certain.: không chắc

children.name: unsure/uncertain about:không chắc về
examples: ▪ I’m still a bit unsure about how to use this software.

children.name: unsure/uncertain of: không chắc về cái gì
examples: ▪ Many workers are still unsure of their rights.

children.name: unsure/uncertain who/what/whether etc:không chắc ai/cái gì/liệu
examples: ▪ David decided to become a teacher but was uncertain which subject to specialize in.

children.name: doubt
children.definition: a feeling of not being sure whether something is true or correct: nghi ngờ

children.name: doubt about
examples: ▪ There are still some doubts about her suitability for the job.

children.name: doubt as to
examples: ▪ There seems to be some doubt as to what warnings were given.

children.name: wonder
children.definition: to think about something that you are not sure about, and try to guess what is true, what will happen, etc: tự hỏi
examples: ▪ He says he’s had no formal training but when you see how good his work is, you start to wonder.
wonder if/how/whether etc: tự hỏi nếu/liệu/...
▪ I wonder if she’ll recognize me after all these years.
▪ He wondered whether he would be able to find the hotel again.

children.name: not sure
children.definition: không chắc
examples: ▪ ‘What time does the film start?’ ‘I think it’s 8.30, but I’m not sure.’
not sure how/whether/when etc: không chắc như thế nào/liệu/khi nào/...
▪ I’m not sure where she lives.
▪ I’m not sure how long it will take the bus to get there.
not sure about: không chắc về
▪ If you’re not sure about the meaning of a word, look it up in a dictionary
not sure of: không chắc về cái gì
▪ Use the ‘Filesearch’ function if you are not sure of the name of a file.
can’t be surespoken when you think something is true, but you are not completely sure
▪ I can’t be sure, but I think I saw Maggie coming out of the hospital this morning.

children.name: question
children.definition: nounPROBLEM

children.name: not quite
children.definition: used to express that you are not certain about something
examples: _I don't quite know what to say.
_I didn't quite catch what he said.

children.name: uncertainty
children.definition: 1 when you feel doubt about what will happen:
examples: Times of great change are also times of uncertainty.
uncertainty about/as to
There is a great deal ofuncertaintyaboutthecompany’sfuture.
2[ countable usually plural ] a situation which you are not sure about because you do not know what will happen :
life’s uncertainties
uncertainty of
the uncertainties of old age

children.name: used when you cannot or do not want to be exact about the information you are giving
examples: _The event was held insomepark or other.
_We'll findsomeoneor other to help us.

children.name: indefinitely
children.definition: adverb

children.name: for a period of time with no fixed end
examples: _The negotiations have beenput off/postponedindefinitely.

children.name: questionable
children.definition: adjective

children.name: not certain, or wrong in some way
examples: _Itis questionablewhether this goal can be achieved.
_Much of late-night television is of questionablevalue/taste.
